review.title: Realizing RCC8 networks using convex regions
review.abstract: In this report we provide the proofs of lemmas 11-14 from the following paper: Steven Schockaert, Sanjiang Li. Realizing RCC8 networks using convex regions, Artificial Intelligence, to appear.

metadata.title: Realizing RCC8 networks using convex regions

sections.text: RCC8 is a popular fragment of regional computation, in which qualitative spatial relationships between regions, such as adjacency, overlap, and parthood, can be expressed. While RCC8 is essentially dimensionless, most current applications are limited to considerations of a two-dimensional or three-dimensional physical space. However, the goal of this paper is to analyze how confinement to convex regions limits the feasibility of networks of RCC8 relationships. First, we identify all the ways in which the meaning of RCC8 base relationships can be limited to ensure that consistent networks in 1D, 2D, 3D, and 4D can be realized beneficially. Most surprisingly, we find that when the relationship "partially overlaps," all consistent euccepsional networks can be realized using consistent 2D, 2D, 3D, and 4D.

sections.heading: 2. Preliminaries
sections.text: In this section, we will give some background information on regional calculation, convex polytopes and the moment curve. We assume that the reader is familiar with basic topological terms, such as open and closed sentences and internal and closure operators, as well as basic geometric terms, such as the convex hull. Throughout the essay, we will use Greek uppercase letters, e.g. for sentences of RCC8 or RCC5 formulas, and uppercase letters, e.g. S for other sentences. We will use lowercase Greek letters, e.g. λ and θ for real numbers, and lowercase letters, such as p and q for dots. We will use bold lowercase letters, e.g. h for vectors.

sections.heading: 2.2. Convex polytopes and the moment curve
sections.text: We first remember a number of terms and results about convex polytopes. A convex polytope V in Rn is the intersection of a finite series of hemispheres, i.e.V = n i = 1 {x-hi · x ≤ ci, x-Rn}, where hi-Rn is a vector and ci-R is a constant. The corresponding hyperplanesHi = {x-hi · x = ci, x-Rn} are called the limiting hyperplanes of V. We call F an n − 1 dimensional face of V, if F = Hi-V and dimensions (F) = n − 1, where Hi is one of the limiting hyperplanes of V. A family of convex polypoles {V1,..., Vm} in Rn is called a neighboring moment, when dim (Vi-Vj) = n − 1 for all 1 ≤ i < j-R2 ≤ m. It is known that adjacent families in R2 can have most of the 3 elements.

sections.heading: 3. Overview of the results
sections.text: In some areas of application of the RCC5 base relationships, for which the results are summarized in figures, we will find the results of the RCC5 base relationships in terms of the required number of dimensions. In other areas of application, we will find an overview of the results of the RCC8 base relationships. In other areas of application, there are no concepts that partially overlap. As we will show, any consistent atomic RCC8 network without the conventional realization of the RCC8 base relationships is excluded in the R4 base relationships. In other areas of application of the RCC8 base relationships, we will find an overview of the results of the RCC8 base relationships. In other areas of application of the RCC5 base relationships, we will also consider subsets of the RCC5 base relationships, for which the results of the RCC5 base relationships are summarized. In other areas of application, we can find an overview of the results of the RCC5 base relationships, which are specified in the RCC8 base relationships.

sections.heading: 4. Restricting the set of RCC8 and RCC5 base relations
sections.text: In Section 4.1, we focus on the fragments that can be realized in R convex; in Section 4.2, we focus on the fragments that can be realized in R2 convex, and we show that these fragments can generally not be realized in R convex. In Section 4.3, we focus on the fragments that can be realized in R3 convex, but not in R2. The main result is presented in Section 4.4, where we present a construction based on the four-dimensional moment curve to show that consistent nuclear networks can be realized in R3 convex via {EC, DC, TPP, TPP − 1, NTPP, NTPP − 1} in R4 convex. We also provide a counter-example to show that networks using {EC, DC, TPP − 1} in R3 can generally not be realized convex. Finally, in Section 4.5, we use general theories to identify fragments that do not allow for realizations in R3.

sections.heading: 4.2. Fragments with convex solutions in R2
sections.text: In this section, we will consider limitations on the set of RCC8 or RCC5 base relationships that guarantee that networks in R2 can be convex. To show that this limit cannot generally be reinforced in terms of the number of dimensions, we will first show in Section 4.2.1 that the fragments considered in R cannot always be convex.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text: We have investigated how the consistency problem for RCC8 networks is influenced by the requirement that all regions must be convex. Previous results on convexity in RCC8 have been largely negative: for each specified number of dimensions k, deciding whether a consistent RCC8 network with convex regions in Rk can be realized is mathematically difficult [23]. In contrast, we have identified a number of important sufficient conditions under which consistent RCC8 networks have convex solutions. First, we have identified all constraints on the set of basic relationships that guarantee that consistent atomic networks in R, R2, R3 and R4 can be realized convexibly. Second, we have identified an upper limit that only depends on the number of regions, i.e. any consistent RCC8 network with most 2n + 1 regions can be realized by example.

referenceMentions.context: RCC8 is a well-known constraint language for modelling and reasoning about the qualitative spatial relationships that hold between regions [1].
In general, constraint networks over RCC8 (or RCC5) relations could be realized using regions from arbitrary topological spaces that satisfy the axioms of the RCC [1].
For example, [2] uses RCC8 to encode how different objects in a video are spatially related to each other, and how these relations change over time.
On the semantic web, RCC8 is used to encode geographic information in OWL ontologies [3, 4] and linked data [5, 6], and to reason about the integrity of spatial databases [7].
On the semantic web, RCC8 is used to encode geographic information in OWL ontologies [3, 4] and linked data [5, 6], and to reason about the integrity of spatial databases [7].
On the semantic web, RCC8 is used to encode geographic information in OWL ontologies [3, 4] and linked data [5, 6], and to reason about the integrity of spatial databases [7].
On the semantic web, RCC8 is used to encode geographic information in OWL ontologies [3, 4] and linked data [5, 6], and to reason about the integrity of spatial databases [7].
On the semantic web, RCC8 is used to encode geographic information in OWL ontologies [3, 4] and linked data [5, 6], and to reason about the integrity of spatial databases [7].
It can be shown that focusing on Euclidean spaces of fixed dimension does not affect the notion of consistency which is used in RCC8 [8] (see Section 2).

For example, in the theory of conceptual spaces proposed in [9], the meaning of natural properties and concepts is represented using convex regions in a suitable metric space, which is most often taken to be Euclidean [9].

For example, in the theory of conceptual spaces proposed in [9], the meaning of natural properties and concepts is represented using convex regions in a suitable metric space, which is most often taken to be Euclidean [9].

While the idea that natural concepts tend to be convex is a conjecture, among other examples, [9] points to evidence from cognitive studies on color spaces, showing that natural language terms for colors tend to correspond to convex regions in a suitable conceptual space .
Requiring convexity is also closely related to prototype theory [10].
In machine learning, convex hull based classifiers have been proposed [11], which are explicitly based on the assumption that categories tend to correspond to convex regions in a feature space.

As an alternative, in [12] a classifier is introduced which encodes the intuition that when x is located between two items from class Ci in the feature space, then x is also likely to belong to class Ci.
In computational linguistics, methods are studied to learn representations for the meaning of natural language terms as convex regions from large corpora [13].
This notion of conceptual neighborhood has proven useful for defining commonsense reasoning approaches to merge conflicting propositional knowledge bases [15].
Alternatively, the exact boundaries of what it means for an object to be orange may be considered to be vague, but we may still use an RCC8 based representation in such a case [9], e.
by relying on the Egg-Yolk calculus [16] or on a fuzzy region connection calculus [17].
by relying on the Egg-Yolk calculus [16] or on a fuzzy region connection calculus [17].
In any case, qualitative spatial reasoning based on (a variant of) RCC8 is well-suited for formalising particular forms of commonsense reasoning about natural language concepts [9].
in [18], RCC5 is combined with a notion of betweenness to formalize interpolation, a particular form of commonsense reasoning.

As another example of qualitative reasoning about convex regions in higher-dimensional Euclidean spaces, we consider species distribution models [19], which are used in ecology to specify the environmental parameters within which the occurrence of a given species can be sustained.
As a final example, we consider imprecise probability theory [20], which is a theory of uncertainty in which the beliefs of an agent are encoded as a convex region called a credal set.

A natural question is then: how does the requirement that all regions be convex affect the realizability of RCC8 constraint networks? It is easy to see that deciding whether an RCC8 network has a convex solution in R can be reduced to consistency checking in the interval algebra [21], which is NP-complete [22].

A natural question is then: how does the requirement that all regions be convex affect the realizability of RCC8 constraint networks? It is easy to see that deciding whether an RCC8 network has a convex solution in R can be reduced to consistency checking in the interval algebra [21], which is NP-complete [22].
In [23] it was shown that deciding whether an RCC8 constraint network can be realized as convex regions in R is decidable, but computationally hard.
Specifically, this problem was shown to be as hard as deciding consistency in the existential theory of the real numbers [24].
Moreover, [23] shows that any RCC8 network which has a convex solution in R can be realized using convex polytopes.

Note that as the required number of dimensions depends on the number of variables in the constraint network, this result does not contradict the result from [23], which applies only if the number of dimensions k is fixed in advance.
In computational linguistics, for instance, it is common to consider highdimensional Euclidean spaces of 100 to 500 dimensions to represent the meaning of natural language terms [13, 25].
In computational linguistics, for instance, it is common to consider highdimensional Euclidean spaces of 100 to 500 dimensions to represent the meaning of natural language terms [13, 25].
If we use RCC8 to reason about convex regions in these spaces, we can use standard RCC8 reasoners [26] if the number of considered regions is at most 2n + 1 = 1001 (in the case of 500 dimensions).
Finally note that Section 5 of this paper presents a substantially revised and extended version of the results from [27].

metadata.abstractText: RCC8 is a popular fragment of the region connection calculus, in which qualitative spatial relations between regions, such as adjacency, overlap and parthood, can be expressed. While RCC8 is essentially dimensionless, most current applications are confined to reasoning about two-dimensional or threedimensional physical space. In this paper, however, we are mainly interested in conceptual spaces, which typically are high-dimensional Euclidean spaces in which the meaning of natural language concepts can be represented using convex regions. The aim of this paper is to analyze how the restriction to convex regions constrains the realizability of networks of RCC8 relations. First, we identify all ways in which the set of RCC8 base relations can be restricted to guarantee that consistent networks can be convexly realized in respectively 1D, 2D, 3D, and 4D. Most surprisingly, we find that if the relation ‘partially overlaps’ is disallowed, all consistent atomic RCC8 networks can be convexly realized in 4D. If instead refinements of the relation ‘part of’ are disallowed, all consistent atomic RCC8 relations can be convexly realized in 3D. We furthermore show, among others, that any consistent RCC8 network with 2n + 1 variables can be realized using convex regions in the n-dimensional Euclidean space.
